comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: There's a great range of ages, some promising moustaches and some mature ones. They were no inter -cert classs at any rate. Look at the banding on the hurl of the young lad to the priests left? It is almost a lethal weapon with that metal banding. I had a hurl like that once and it was positively dangerous and a threat to life, it lasted for years but! The writing on the hurl held by the man third from the left in the middle row says "Coolagown" which is a place near Fermoy in Cork and seems to have had strong Waterford connections. See www.castlelyonsgaa.com/clubHistory.php

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Best to remember that it was a teacher training college and thus attracted students from all over. Funny though, most people in Waterford never use the word hurl, except when throwing things. Hurley is the preferred description, Perhaps that explains a lot?

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: A wonderful old photo and taken at my old school. When I went here in the 70's there were boarders from all over the country there.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Ah, a De La Salle boy! And [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] when did it stop being a teacher training college?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: I believe it was in 1936 when the Minister for Education Tom Derrig (FF) refused to have it made a constituent college of the NUI.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Look what Garswood_latic did with this photo! Very subtly colourised, methinks...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Long shot (if you'll pardon the pun), but any idea of what colours the jerseys at your Alma Mater might have been back in 1910?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I'm not sure but very likely dark red & gold, those have been the colours as long as I can remember.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] So [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63589068@N04/] has come very close with his colourisation...
